Speaker: second draft
Dialogue: October 22, 1998

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Do you think he's really dying?

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: He's been dying for ten years.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: I think he's really dying this time.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: He has to be bled every night now.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: How do you know that?

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: I've been so informed.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: If he weren't really dying he wouldn't have sent for us.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Maybe he just misses us.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: And the Senators.  He wouldn't have summoned them if --

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Peace, Commodus.  After two weeks on the road your incessant scheming is hurting my head.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: The first thing I shall do is honor him with games worthy of his majesty.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: The first thing I shall do is have a hot bath.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Why have we stopped?

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Where is my father?

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Is the battle won?

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Take me to my father.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Civilization at last.  Gods preserve us.

Speaker: titus
Dialogue: You would do as well to read the mind of a rhinoceros.

Speaker: quintus
Dialogue: These barbarians would rather drown in blood than yield an inch.  If I didn't hate them so much I would admire them.

Speaker: titus
Dialogue: They simply will not surrender.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: A people should know when they are conquered.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: At the first signal release the catapults.  We'll use the cavalry to cut off the retreat.

Speaker: quintus
Dialogue: General, I don't recommend that. Our cavalry might be caught in the flames.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I hope not, because I'm going to be leading them.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Why don't they know they're already dead?

Speaker: quintus
Dialogue: Now!

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Hold steady... steady...

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Steady...

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Brothers -- I salute you!  For Rome!

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Caesar.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Maximus, you prove your valor again. Let us hope for the final time here.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I don't think there's anyone left to fight.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: There are always people left to fight...

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: But this night, at least, Germania is at last defeated... What will you do now, my friend?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Should Caesar permit, I'll go home. I've been away too long.  I've forgotten my wife's face and I barely know my son.

Speaker: german prisoner
Dialogue: THIS BLOOD MEANS NOTHING, CONQUEROR!

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: ... You speak our language?

Speaker: german prisoner
Dialogue: You have been in my homeland for twelve years.  Of course I speak your language.  So did my son, who you murdered.  So did my daughter, who you raped.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Come, Caesar...

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: No.  Let him speak...  ... I am Rome, what would you say to me?

Speaker: german prisoner
Dialogue: You are that sun, Rome, and your time is over... You can slit a thousand throats here, and you can put a thousand babies to the sword, but it will always be our home.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Now it is Rome.

Speaker: german prisoner
Dialogue: It will never be Rome.  Not as long as one German breathes.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: No... Release him.  Give him safe passage.  Let him go to his family.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Tell me again, Maximus, why are we here?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: For the glory of the empire, sire.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Yes.  I remember.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: They honor you, Caesar.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: I don't think they're standing for me, Maximus.  They honor you.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Have I missed it?

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Have I missed the battle?

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: You've missed the war.  We're done here.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Father.  Congratulations.  I shall sacrifice a thousand doves to honor your triumph.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Spare the doves and honor Maximus, he won the battle.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: General, Rome salutes you and I embrace you as a brother.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Highness.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Your Spaniards seem invincible.  May the Gods favor the Felix Regiment now and always...  Here, Father, take my arm.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Where's your sister?

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: She's at the camp.  She had no desire to see the gore of the battlefield.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Lucilla would eat every corpse here if it brought her one step closer to the throne.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Caesar, you do the lady injustice.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: It's a foolish old cobra who doesn't recognize his own off-spring...  I think... I should ride now.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: So much for the glory of Rome.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: He's dying.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Poor old man.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: If you'll excuse me, Highness.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: What, Gallus, losing your other hand?

Speaker: gallus
Dialogue: Aye, General, they're going to make a bronze one for it.  Long fingers this time.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: And the women of your village will crave your touch even more.

Speaker: gallus
Dialogue: Ah, then you know the women of my village.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: What's your name, son?

Speaker: valerius
Dialogue: Valerius, General.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: The name suits you.

Speaker: valerius
Dialogue: Why am I dying?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: You're dying because you love Rome, as I do.

Speaker: valerius
Dialogue: I've never been to Rome.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Neither have I.  Rome for us lives here...  ... it's a thing inside us that came from our ancestors and that we give to our children.

Speaker: valerius
Dialogue: It must be glorious, Rome.  I've only seen pictures.  Is it a glorious place?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Yes, it's a glorious place.

Speaker: valerius
Dialogue: It must be.

Speaker: falco
Dialogue: Hail, Marcus Aurelius.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Stand up, Senators.  That unfamiliar posture doesn't suit you.

Speaker: gaius
Dialogue: We live in supplication to your glory.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: All the while conspiring with that fat man in Rome.  How is the old monster?

Speaker: gaius
Dialogue: Senator Gracchus is hale, sire.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Still damning me to the four winds?

Speaker: gaius
Dialogue: Still eager for your triumphant return to Rome, Caesar.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: I would have silenced him decades ago -- but I just like him too much.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: If you want to stay on, I support you.  So do the men.  I'll ask the Emperor to appoint you in my place.

Speaker: titus
Dialogue: It won't be the Felix Regiment without you.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I'll return after a season at home. Maybe two.

Speaker: quintus
Dialogue: That means after three or four more babies.

Speaker: titus
Dialogue: And you'll be too fat from Vibia's cooking to get on your horse by then.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Should the Gods so bless me.  I would be thankful.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Hail, warriors.  My congratulations.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: My old friend, my father tells me you're returning to Spain?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: A pity.  I'll need men like you in my army...

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: There are larger division that might appeal to you.  Even the Praetorian Guard.  You've never been to Rome. Imagine arriving as head of the Praetorians!  They have really splendid uniforms.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I'm going home.

Speaker: gaius
Dialogue: ... And why not apply for entry to the Senate?

Speaker: falco
Dialogue: A war hero with a handsome face and a strong heart could go far.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: General Maximus, may I present Senators Gaius and Falco.  Beware of this Gaius, he'll pour a honeyed potion in your ear and you'll wake up one day and all you'll say is "Republic, Republic, Republic..."

Speaker: falco
Dialogue: Have you never considered Rome?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: You've had my ear since we were children.  You could be a valuable ally in the Senate.

Speaker: gaius
Dialogue: Are you a believer in Republicanism?

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: There -- I warned you.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I'm a soldier, not a politician.

Speaker: gaius
Dialogue: If your heart lies with the people, I would back you for the Senate. I'm sure Gracchus would as well.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Not a word about that sodomite bastard.

Speaker: gaius
Dialogue: The august Senator Gracchus has been rather a gadfly on the flesh of the imperial family.

Speaker: falco
Dialogue: He's a damned provocateur.

Speaker: gaius
Dialogue: He lives under the antiquated assumption that the Senate should represent the people with vigor.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: I won't tolerate it.  His incessant criticism exhausts me.  The man can speak for five hours without taking a breath.

Speaker: gaius
Dialogue: He serves Rome best when he serves it with honesty.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Enough... Maximus, I would like to inspect the Felix Regiment at dawn. Please arrange it.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I can't do that.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Excuse me?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: My men have been fighting for five solid days.  They're too busy dying to go on dress parade.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Of course, how foolish of me.  Some other time...

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Caesar retires early tonight.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: If only you had been born a man...

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Father.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: What a Caesar you would have made.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: You're right.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: I think you would have been strong. I wonder if you would have been just?

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: I would have been what you taught me to be.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Well, pretend to be my loving daughter tonight and walk with me to my chamber.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: This is a pleasant fiction, isn't it?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Caesar.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Read this.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I never acquired the art, sir.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Of course.  No matter.  In this letter I denote my intention to nominate you to stand for the Emperorship after my death.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: My son is not a moral man.  You have known this since you were young.  He cannot rule.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Caesar, I am honored but --

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: For twenty years I have been spilling blood.  For twenty years I have written philosophy and ruminated and conquered.  Since I became Caesar I have only had four years without war.  Four years of peace in twenty.  So perhaps I can be... forgiven.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: While I have been fighting, Rome has grown mad and corpulent and diseased.  I did this.  And now I shall make it right.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Sire, you brought the light of the Gods to barbarian darkness.  You brought civilization and justice to the farthest --

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: I have brought the sword -- nothing more!  Rome is far away and we shouldn't be here.  What matter is it to the Gods if we subdue one more tribe of Parthians or Gauls?  What matter is it to Rome if a thousand more barbarians bend to our lash?

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Winter, Maximus.  It's winter now...

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: There was a dream that was Rome.  I can only whisper of it now. Anything more than a whisper and the dream vanishes.  It's so... fragile. The true glory of Rome is in a very fragile idea.  Imagine a place devoted to the rights of the citizen.  Where every free man has a voice.  That was the dream... And I fear it will not survive the winter.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Let's just whisper here, you and I.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Yes, Caesar.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: If the dream is ever to live again the people must have a true voice. The voice I took from them.  That all the Caesars took from them, bit by bit, conquest by conquest.  And now that I am dying I am going to give them that voice again.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: You're not dying.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: I am, Maximus.  It's strange... I find as I near the end I think little of the waning moments around me... instead I think much of the past... and of the future.  How will the world speak my name in years to come?  Will I be known as the philosopher?  The warrior?  The tyrant?  Or will there be a more golden sounding to my name?  Will I be the Emperor who gave Rome back her freedom?

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Before I die I will give the people this final gift.  I will give them the Senate reborn.  The voice of the people empowered again, as it was always meant to be.  It is my design that they will elect the next Emperor.  And I would put forward your name with my backing.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Caesar, you do me honor -- but your son has pride of place for succession.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: You are the son I should have had... Although I fear in my deepest heart that if you had truly been my son my blood would have polluted you as it did Commodus.  We're a cursed bloodline.  We have lived so long in power and depravity that we no longer remember a life without it. We can no longer even imagine a life without it.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Look at me, son.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Son... I know that one grove of your vineyard is worth more to you than all the treasures of Rome.  I know one loving word from your wife is worth more than the accolades of an Empire.  But... a fond old man, who loves you more than he can say, begs you to at least think about what he has said tonight.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I shall, Caesar.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: I'll keep this letter to myself.  I hope that with the sunrise you will agree.  And embrace me as a father.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: You have always been my father.

Speaker: lucilla's voice
Dialogue: He always favored you...

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Even over his son.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: That's not true.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Maximus, stop...  Let me see your face.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: You've been crying.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I lost too many men.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: What does my father intend?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: You're lying.  I could tell when you were lying even when we were children.  You hate it.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I never acquired your comfort with it.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: True.  But then you never had to. Maximus, stop...  ... Is it really so terrible seeing me again?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: No.  I'm sorry.  I'm tired from the battle.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: And you are hurt to see my father dying.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: He will announce Commodus' succession.  That's why he summoned us.  Will you serve my brother as you served his father?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I will always serve the ideals of Rome.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Do you know I still remember you in my prayers...?  Oh yes, I pray... Ever since that day you saved me from drowning off Capri.  Do you remember?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Commodus was so angry that a mere peasant -- a Spaniard no less -- touched the royal person, do you remember his anger?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Mark this, Maximus:  that is the man who will be Emperor.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: May I be permitted to go, Highness?

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: There was a time when you didn't call me "Highness."

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: And there was a time when you were just a little girl drowning in the sea.  All that was a different life.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Very different... I wonder if it was better?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: It was more honest.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I thank you for your prayers.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Ancestors, true bloodline, I ask you for your guidance.  Bring me your solace and your wisdom.  Blessed Mother, come to me in my dreams with the Gods' desire for my future. Blessed Father, watch over my wife and my son with a ready sword.  Keep them safe until my return.  Whisper to them in their sleep that I live only to hold them again and all else is dust and air.  Ancestors, true bloodline, I honor you and will try to live with the dignity you have taught me.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: I search the faces of the Gods for ways to please you... to make you proud... and I can never do it.  One kind word -- one full hug where you pressed me to your chest and held me tight -- would have been like the sun on my heart for a thousand years... What is it in me you hate so much?  My eyes are your eyes.  My hands are your hands.  All I have ever wanted was to live up to you. Caesar.  Father.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Why does Maximus deserve what I could never have? -- Why do you love his eyes over mine? -- I would butcher the whole world -- if you would only love me...

Speaker: quintus
Dialogue: General -- Maximus --

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Quintus -- ?

Speaker: quintus
Dialogue: The Emperor needs you.  It's urgent.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: What is it?  Is he ill?

Speaker: quintus
Dialogue: I don't know...

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Lament with me, brother, our great father is dead.  I want --

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: General, the Gods' have taken the great man and left me alone.  My first desire as Emperor is that you take my hand in friendship.  I need you at my side, Maximus, at this moment above all others.  Stand with me.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: How did he die?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: How did he die?

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: The surgeons say it was his breath that gave out.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Take my hand, Maximus.  I only offer it once.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: How will the world speak your name now, old man?

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Hail, Caesar.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: What -- ?!

Speaker: quintus
Dialogue: Please don't fight, Maximus --

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Quintus --

Speaker: quintus
Dialogue: I'm sorry, General, Caesar has spoken.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Quintus, what -- ?

Speaker: quintus
Dialogue: I have no choice --

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: My family?!

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: What about my family, Quintus?

Speaker: quintus
Dialogue: They will greet you in the afterlife.

Speaker: quintus
Dialogue: Take him as far as the sunrise and then kill him.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Have you ever done this before?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Killed a man with a sword?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: It can be very messy -- you could get blood all over your armor.  You don't want to hack me up now.  You want one clean stroke.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: One good stroke -- you do know where, don't you?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: If you miss the spot there'll be blood everywhere.  Quite a spray.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Here -- you don't want to hit the vein on the neck --

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Put the point of your sword here... you want one, good blow right at this spot --

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Even as the Gods curse this dark day with clouds, so too does the sun begin to shine forth on a promised tomorrow.  Even as we mourn the passing of our father, so too do we celebrate the coming of a bright, new age for Rome.  At my side, brothers, you shall pull fresh glories from the heavens.  At my side, brothers, you shall know the adoration of the Gods.  Doubly-dark is this day because my friend, your noble commander Maximus Meridas, has been called to Rome to deal with urgent matters of state...

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Until his promised return I appointed Quintus Domitian to serve in his stead.  I salute you, Legionnaires!

Speaker: quintus
Dialogue: Hail, Caesar!

Speaker: felix regiment
Dialogue: Hail, Caesar!

Speaker: titus
Dialogue: Quintus, what is -- ?

Speaker: quintus
Dialogue: Don't speak of it.  Never speak of it.

Speaker: maximus' son
Dialogue: MOTHER!  MOTHER!  FATHER'S HOME!

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Am I in Hades?

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: For your wound...

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: For your wound.

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: If you die in the wagons they feed you to the lions... The lions are worth more than we are.  I think we are worth more than the zebras though.  So they don't feed us to them.

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: I'm not sure about the giraffe.

Speaker: slave trader
Dialogue: Proximo, my old friend, see what I have for you today -- !

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Those giraffes you sold me won't mate!  All they do is run around not mating!  YOU SOLD ME EUNUCH GIRAFFES!!

Speaker: slave trader
Dialogue: I will make it up to you, Master. It's bargain day for you!  Look, look, look -- I have two lions and a panther -- hear how they roar for you!  "Bring me home, Proximo!"

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: How much for the lot?

Speaker: slave trader
Dialogue: For you -- 8,000 sesterces.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: For me -- 6,000 sesterces and I want to see their balls first.  And you throw in those two slaves.

Speaker: slave trader
Dialogue: What about this one?  Look at the arms!

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Good teeth --

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Where did you get those scars?

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Are you a soldier?

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Do you speak? --  He's dying.

Speaker: slave trader
Dialogue: 1,000 sesterces.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: My ass...  You throw in this one and we'll make it 7,000 sesterces for the whole lot.

Speaker: slave trader
Dialogue: I have to eat, Master!  He's my finest, I couldn't let him go as part of the lot for less than 9,000 total...  I tell you this one is prime.  He's a Spaniard and killed fourteen of my men before he could be subdued!

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: All right, let's see.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: That's enough.

Speaker: slave trader
Dialogue: STOP!  STOP!

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: I'll give you 500 sesterces.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Come, don't quibble with your old friend.  I'll take the lions, the panther, the Numidian and this one for 7,000.  And I'll buy you the best whore in the town for two nights.  She's an enormous mountain of flesh who craves a stern hand.

Speaker: slave trader
Dialogue: How could I say no to my old friend Proximo?

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: COME ON, YOU FILTHY BEAST!

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Slaves.  I am Proximo, trainer of gladiators.  You live and die at my pleasure.  Fight well and you will live.  Fight poorly and you will die.  It is better to live.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Here you will be trained in the art of combat.  Here you will be given the tools to survive.  Please my patrons in the arena and all the gifts of the world will be showered upon you.  Imagine riches beyond your paltry dreams of riches! Imagine fame beyond your rude understanding of the word!  All this can belong to the select few who prove their worth in the arena.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: If... on the other hand... you disappoint me... you will be dismembered and fed to my jackals limb by limb.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: And my jackals are always hungry.

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: Have you killed a man before?

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: You should eat.  You'll need your strength tomorrow.

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: I've never killed a man.  But I think you have.

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: I almost killed once.  The Romans destroyed my village.  I was with a hunting party and when we returned... I would have killed every Roman in the world.

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: If you don't eat you will die.

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: In the village I come from there was a man once.  He went fishing one day and his boat was attacked by crocodiles.  One of them ate his leg.  He pulled himself to the shore and a lion attacked him.  It ate one of his arms.  He dragged himself through the desert on the way home and a scorpion stung his eye.  So he only had one eye.  When he reached the village I sat with him.  I said, "You have lost a leg, an arm and one eye.  You must have a mighty will to live."  He said, "No, Lord, it's just better than the alternative."

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: Life is a gift from our fathers to us.  Who are you to give it up for lack of lifting a spoon?

Speaker: scribe
Dialogue: I know nothing of armaments and warfare!  I'm a scribe -- I write down words!  I can write down seven languages --

Speaker: vibius
Dialogue: Be still.

Speaker: scribe
Dialogue: I don't -- how do you hold the sword?!  I've never held a sword!

Speaker: vibius
Dialogue: You point the sharp end at your opponent and you shove it in his guts.

Speaker: scribe
Dialogue: I can't -- I --

Speaker: vibius
Dialogue: Proximo!  You insult me with this carrion!  Chain him to someone else!

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Don't worry, noble Vibius, he won't be bothering you for long.

Speaker: children
Dialogue: Dead guts!  Dead guts!  Dead guts!

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Some of you say you can't fight, you won't fight... They all say that... But one day you will pick up a sword and thrust it into another man.  And the crowd will cheer you and love you.  And you will love them for it. On that day... you will be a gladiator.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: In this life, we all die.  All we can choose is how we die.  And how we are remembered.  Be remembered proudly.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: No...  ... give the Spaniard to him.  Give the Scribe to Vibius.

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: Are we going to fight each other?

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Make it 600 sesterces for each decapitation.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Two.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Done.  400 sesterces for two strokes.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: A Greek Scribe.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Give me odds, friend.

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: We have plague in the Hebrew Quarter and it is spreading... we have looting at the granaries... we have so much filth in the Tiber that the water is undrinkable... we have Praetorian Guard units that are demanding protection payments from the merchants at the exchange --

Speaker: marcellus
Dialogue: My City Guard units have tried to curtail these excesses but no constabulary can police the entire city.  And the Praetorians outnumber us two to one.

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: Rome dies as the Emperor plays at beneficence.  At least Nero gave us music!

Speaker: gaius
Dialogue: Do you think he'll listen to us?

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: It is his duty to hear the will of the Senate.

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: Not to mention the damn traffic!

Speaker: child
Dialogue: We honor Caesar with the laurel to show our love and appreciation for his benevolence.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Caesar is honored to accept your tribute, Citizen Scholar.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: It is the most sacred duty of the Emperor to oversee the education of the young.  If I could leave no other legacy than the scholarship of all children my life would be blessed.  Tutors, you hold the future of Rome in your hands.  Teach them well so that they will bring honor to the Empire.  I salute you.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Look at them, Senators... my truest gift to Rome.

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: Darling children, to be sure, now if I may proceed?

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Very well...

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: Caesar, your presence in Rome is an invaluable opportunity to begin correcting some of the ills that have beset the city since your father went to the wars.  We would like to --

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Peace, good Gracchus, peace...

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: My beloved father was a careless shepherd to his flock.  I shall be a good father to my children.  I shall remain in Rome and show them how they are loved.

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: With respect, sire, the people don't need love -- they need law.  The Senate has prepared a series of protocols to begin addressing the corruption in the city --  -- starting with basic sanitation in the Hebrew Quarter.  If Caesar could study this and --

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: You see that's the very problem, isn't it, my old, old friend?  My father spent all his time at study. At books and learning and philosophy...

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: He spent his twilight hours reading scrolls from the Senate.  All the while, the people were forgotten.

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: The Senate is the people.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: I doubt many of the people eat so well as you do, Senator Gracchus...

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: I doubt many of the people have such splendid armor, Captain Marcellus. Or such fine mistresses, Senator Gaius.  No... only their true father knows what the people need.  I shall show them they are loved.  I shall hold them to my bosom and embrace them tightly --

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: Have you ever embraced someone dying of plague, sire?

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: No.  But if you interrupt me one more time I assure you that you shall.  I will emulate the immortal Caesars of the past.  I will give the people what they truly want. Starting this day I will draw all of Rome to the Colosseum.  I will give them bread.  And they will want nothing more.

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: You want to hold games?

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Not just any games, Senator!  A series of games that will make the Gods envious and leave my children happy!  I will subsidize the arena from this day forth -- and I will culminate this celebration in a great spectacle the likes of which the world has never seen!  A great spectacle to honor my father! Magnificent, unending weeks of festivity all in the name of Marcus Aurelius!

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: If I may, Caesar... how are you going to pay for this?

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: That is not your concern.

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: Respectfully, sire, taxation and import duties are the exclusive province of the Senate --

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: MY FATHER DESERVES TO BE HONORED AND I WILL HONOR HIM! -- AND THE PEOPLE WILL LOVE ME! -- AND THE SENATE WILL OBEY ME OR EVERY ONE OF YOU WILL BURN!  BURN!  BURN! -- I WILL HAVE ORDER!

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Gentlemen, in the future do not concern my brother with these matters.  Come to me.

Speaker: marcellus
Dialogue: Games?  He wants to hold games?

Speaker: gaius
Dialogue: It's madness.

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: No... it's not...

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: He knows who Rome is.  Rome is the mob.  He will conjure magic for them and they will be distracted.  And he will takes their lives.  And he will take their freedom.  And still they will roar.  The beating heart of Rome isn't the marble of the Senate. It's the sand of the Colosseum.  He will give them death.  And they will love him for it.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: I've wagered on you against the Celts -- ignore the others and go for them -- there are two axe-and- net and two long spear.  Now the Celts aren't used to the sun so you have the advantage there...

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: And keep them moving, their lungs aren't strong, ground the spears as soon as you can and then go for the ax-men.  If you get all four there's an extra bonus so don't be distracted by the Spartans...

Speaker: vibius
Dialogue: MOVE ASIDE!  THIS IS A TABLE FOR MEN!

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Butterfly?

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Perhaps you'd like a woman?

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Boy?

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Gold?

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Well, I have nothing left to offer you!  A man who turns down a butterfly, a woman, a boy and gold confuses me.  Personally, I'd grab them all and then grab some more because the Gods are fanciful and take us at their whim.  Does the Spaniard have any needs?

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: You fight like a soldier.  You have wounds like a soldier who has been on long campaigns.  You eye the world around you like an enemy. What is your name, Roman soldier?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Gladiator.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: And nothing more?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Nothing more.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: In two days we leave for Rome.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Ah... so it's Rome you want.  Well you shall have her, Gladiator.  The new Emperor has ordered a series of matches to culminate in a grand spectacle.  If you do well I shall become very, very rich.  If you do well enough I shall set you free. Is it freedom you want?

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Not even that.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: The Emperor -- will he be there?

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Oh yes.  He's apparently quite mad about the games.  Spending a fortune, which is, needless to say, good for me again.  But what is good for you, Gladiator?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Have you -- how does one meet the Emperor?

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: As a gladiator?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: One doesn't.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Except... If one has proven oneself in battle.  If at the end of the games you are the final man standing -- the Emperor will present you with a small wooden sword.  The sword is your freedom.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: He give it personally?

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: He did to me...  Our great father Marcus Aurelius looked into my eyes and touched me on the shoulder.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: You knew Marcus?

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: I didn't know him.  He touched me on the shoulder.  Just once.  But that was enough.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: All right, Gladiator.  We shall go to Rome together and have bloody adventures.  The Great Whore will suckle us until we are fat and happy and can't suck another drop.  That is Rome.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: All my desires are splitting my head to pieces -- there's so much I want to do -- but all my efforts to show my children they are loved go unappreciated by those dragons in the Senate --

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Quiet, brother...

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Leave the Senate to me.  Don't trouble yourself.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: All I want is to be a good father to my people.  Why don't they understand that?

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Shhh.  The tonic will help...

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Yes, just drink this down.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: I must take a firmer hand with them. They must know their father can be firm.  As our father was firm with us.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Our father lost his way.  His mistake was believing the old songs of the "Republic."  We know better. So let the Senate talk.  They have no real power.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Yes... yes... you always know the way.  You were always so wise in these matters...  You know if I didn't have my duty to Rome I think I should be an artist. I should go away and paint pictures of the sea and leave all the politics to you...

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Will you stay with me?

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Still afraid of the dark, brother?

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Still.  Always.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: My dreams would terrify the world.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: I'll stay with you until you are asleep.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: And after... just sit with me.  Keep me safe...

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: He's asleep.  Be quick.

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: We've taking a sounding, the Senate is with us.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Good.

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: But we are only words.  We are air. We need steel.

Speaker: marcellus
Dialogue: The City Guard is faithful to the Republic.  But we don't stand a chance against the Praetorians.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Can they be bought?

Speaker: marcellus
Dialogue: They are zealots -- totally committed to your brother.

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: Well, can they at least be rented for a day?

Speaker: marcellus
Dialogue: I doubt it.  He pays them exorbitant salaries and lets them loot and extort as they see fit.  The city belongs to them.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: And they've started arresting scholars now.  Anyone who dares speak out -- even satirists and chroniclers.

Speaker: marcellus
Dialogue: And mathematicians and Christians. All to fill the arena.

Speaker: gaius
Dialogue: And what pays for it?  These games are costing a fortune and yet we have no new taxes.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: The future.  The future pays for it...

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: He's started selling the grain reserves.

Speaker: gaius
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: marcellus
Dialogue: That can't be true...

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: He's selling Rome's reserves of grain.  The people will be starving in two years.  I hope they are enjoying the spectacles because soon enough they will be dead because of them.

Speaker: marcellus
Dialogue: Rome must know this.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: And who will tell them?!  You, Marcellus?  You, Senator Gaius? Will you make a speech on the Senate floor denouncing my brother?  And then see your family in the Colosseum?  What town-crier would dare?

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: He must die.

Speaker: gaius
Dialogue: The Praetorians would only seize control themselves.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: No -- cut off the head and the snake cannot strike.

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: Lucilla, Gaius is right.  Until the City Guard can neutralize the Praetorians we can accomplish nothing.

Speaker: marcellus
Dialogue: And I haven't enough men.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: What about the army?

Speaker: gaius
Dialogue: No Roman army has entered the capital in a hundred years.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: So we do nothing?!

Speaker: lucius' voice
Dialogue: Mother...

Speaker: lucius
Dialogue: I heard voices...

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: It's all right, darling, you --

Speaker: lucius
Dialogue: Senator!  What did you bring me?!

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: For you prince Lucius... a sea monster!

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: Off the coast of Achaea they grow twenty times this size, with snapping teeth to devour any nasty Praetorians they come across... now, where is Achaea?

Speaker: lucius
Dialogue: Below Macedonia!

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: Show me on the map.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Lucius, you go in now, I'll be in shortly.

Speaker: lucius
Dialogue: Thank you, Senator Mountain!

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: You're welcome, Prince Anthill!

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: What are you going to do?

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: Peace child... One dark night the Gods will light our path.  They will give us the voice we need.  Have faith in that.  Have faith.

Speaker: vibius
Dialogue: Not what you expected?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: vibius
Dialogue: Rome is nothing but a slaughter house.  And we are the meat.

Speaker: vibius
Dialogue: Tradition.  He watches over us.

Speaker: vibius
Dialogue: Oh go on, it won't kill you.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Stop that!  You'll get some monstrous disease and then you'll be worth nothing to me!

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: Do you think it will be much different?  Here in Rome?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Bigger arena.  Same killing.

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: Are you scared for tomorrow?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: Me too.

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: I never though it would be so easy to kill.

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: So you're finally home.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: This isn't my home.

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: For all Romans... this is home.

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: Among my people we honor the soil of our home.  Our ancestors are in that soil.  All their dreams live there. I will never see my home again.  The soil is dead and no one honors them, so the dreams die.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Perhaps one day you'll return.

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: How can I go back?  I am not what I was.  When a man kills for no reason, he has lost himself.

Speaker: cassius
Dialogue: ... and the Emperor will have no more animal battles today --

Speaker: cassius
Dialogue: Talk to the man in the imperial box. Who has the next slot...?  -- Nice to have you back, you piratical bastard -- now listen, the Emperor wants the Carthage spectacle.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: No -- have pity, Cassius -- !

Speaker: cassius
Dialogue: You give us the Carthage match or lose your spot on the rotation -- but don't worry -- gold is flowing from the Emperor's fingers.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: I won't do it for less than 100,000 sesterces -- !

Speaker: cassius
Dialogue: And I want to see this famous Spaniard of yours -- his reputation soars from the provinces.  The people are eager for him --

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: I won't throw my Spaniard into a spectacle!  Damn you and damn the rotation!

Speaker: cassius
Dialogue: You will and the price will be 90,000 sesterces each --  -- which you all know is exorbitant -- AND IF YOU EXTORTING BLOOD-WHORES TRY TO PAWN OFF LESSER FIGHTERS ON ME I WILL SEE YOU DEAD IN THE ARENA TOMORROW!

Speaker: cassius
Dialogue: Give me your best, brothers.  They die before Caesar.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: I give you 30,000 my Spaniard will kill at least one of your Thracians.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Then make the wager, you smug bastard!

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: All right -- there are three other teams, four men each --  You know what a Thracian looks like?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Yes, but --

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Ignore the others -- go for the Thracians.  The sun is to the east -- over the gate -- keep your back to the gate and you won't have the sun.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: What -- ?

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Hurry -- !

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Die well and we'll sing songs about you for a generation.

Speaker: cassius
Dialogue: This day we reach back to hallowed antiquity to bring you... THE FALL OF MIGHTY CARTHAGE...!  ... On the barren armies of the barbarian Hannibal!  Ferocious mercenaries and warriors of all brute nations bent on merciless conquest!  Your Emperor is pleased to give you... THE BARBARIAN HORDE!

Speaker: cassius
Dialogue: But on that illustrious day the Gods sent against them Rome's greatest warriors...!  The very life-image of nobility and glorious valor... who would on this day, and on these same arid Numidian deserts, decide THE FATE OF THE EMPIRE... Your Emperor is pleased to give you... THE LEGIONNAIRES OF SCIPIO AFRICANUS!!

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Slave!  Who are you?

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: SLAVE!  WHO ARE YOU?

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: SLAVE!  WHO ARE YOU?!

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I AM MAXIMUS MERIDAS, GENERAL OF THE FELIX REGIMENT OF THE ROMAN ARMY AND SERVANT TO THE EMPEROR MARCUS AURELIUS!

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I AM FATHER TO A MURDERED SON AND HUSBAND TO A MURDERED WIFE AND LANDLORD TO A MURDERED WORLD -- AND I WILL HAVE VENGEANCE!

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Why is he still alive?

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: He shouldn't be alive.  That vexes me.  I am terribly vexed...

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: There, that's better.  Do you like the platform here?

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Mmm.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: I do too.  Simple, elegant...

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Father would have wanted something more ornate but he's dead now.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Maximus Meridas haunts me.  I see Father turning away from me and gazing at him.  How many times did I suffer that indignity, I wonder?

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: What are you going to do?

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: I'm going to kill him.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Good.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Oh, you're too clever, Sister. Don't tell me part of you won't weep for him.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: When he defies my brother the Emperor, he defies me.  But you shouldn't send assassins.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: No?

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: The people embraced him today.  They will be expecting his next match...  ... let him die in the arena like the slave he is.  Let the people see what comes of defying Caesar.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: He wounded you deeply, didn't he? Long ago.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Nonetheless, your political acumen is, as always, unerring.

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: I will fight with you.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: This isn't your battle.

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: Better to die for a friend than to die for gold.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Enjoy yourself, Madame...  General, perform well and there will be riches for you.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Rich matrons pay well to be pleasured by the bravest champions.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I knew your brother would send assassins.  I didn't think he would send his best.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Maximus, listen to me --

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: My family were crucified and burnt while they were still alive.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: I knew nothing of that.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Don't lie to me.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: I wept for them.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Don't.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Do you know what it is to be the daughter of the Emperor?  I learned on the night my father had my husband killed.  I loved my husband very much.  Very... simply.  He was a man who believed in the Republic. He was a man who thought Marcus should be tending to Rome and not conquering the world.  One night my father had him strangled for conspiring with the Senate.  My father never spoke of it.  I never spoke of it.  That is what it is to be the daughter of Rome.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: My son will live.  He will survive this cursed bloodline.  Rome will die and the jackals will pick her clean -- but my son will survive. Empires come and go.  Cities crumble to dust.  Only family matters.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: My son was innocent.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: So is mine.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I want your brother dead.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: So do I.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: My son will never be safe while he lives.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: How do you plan it?

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: The Senate is with us, and the City Guard.  We have growing power in the streets.  But we need a leader. Someone the people can --

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: So the crown passes to your son.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: No.  So that my son will be safe. So that we may leave this charnel house forever and never look back. Look into my eyes, Maximus, and believe what I say to you...

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: By all the Gods, and in the name of my father who loved you, and in the name of the husband I loved... I swear to stand by your side in this now and always.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: What is your son's name?

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Lucius Verus.  Like his father.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I weep for him.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Commodus plans to kill you in your next match in the arena.  He's planning something.  I will pray for you.  As I have always done.

Speaker: cassius
Dialogue: ... in his majestic charity the Emperor has deigned to this day favor the people of Rome with an historical final match.  Returning to the Colosseum today... after five years in retirement... Caesar is pleased to bring you... THE ONLY UNDEFEATED CHAMPION IN ROMAN HISTORY...  ... THE LEGENDARY... TIGER OF GAUL!!

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Gods!  That old Homicide!  The Emperor must truly hate you.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: What can you tell me?

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: He cheats.

Speaker: cassius
Dialogue: And from the rocky promontories and martial bloodlines of Spain... representing the training lyceum of Proximo Antoninus... I give you... THE WARRIOR MAXIMUS!

Speaker: lucius' voice
Dialogue: Is it true you're a General...?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I was a General.

Speaker: lucius
Dialogue: I saw you fight.  The Carthage battle too.  I've never seen so much courage.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: It doesn't take courage to kill.

Speaker: lucius
Dialogue: My father was killed.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I'm sorry.

Speaker: lucius
Dialogue: He still comes to me in my dreams. Do you have a father?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I had a father.  He wasn't really my father but I cared for him very much.

Speaker: lucius
Dialogue: I hope he comes to you in your dreams.  My father and I ride horses in mine.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Lucius, run along now.  I need to talk to the General.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Where is my army?

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: ... Maximus will summon his army from Ostia and he will strike from the inside as his army strikes from the outside.  But he insists that the Senate be present.

Speaker: gaius
Dialogue: We've been ordered to attend.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: How many are with us?

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: About half.  But once the tyrant is dead.  All.

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: I want to meet him.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: I'll arrange it.

Speaker: gaius
Dialogue: And what of the Emperor?

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: He has withdrawn.  He's not eating. He doesn't go out.  He won't even see me... I don't know what tempests rage within him but...

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: We should fear for the blackest storm.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: gaius
Dialogue: One question... who is to be the actual Regicide?

Speaker: vibius
Dialogue: You didn't kill him.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I will not kill another warrior. There is no honor to it.

Speaker: kids
Dialogue: Maximus the Merciful!  Maximus the Merciful!

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Tell him we will enter Rome on the first day of Commodus' festival.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: And they will march on Rome for you?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Yes.  But this letter must go to the lieutenant named Titus, no one else.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Captain Marcellus will take it.  And his City Guard will by with you when you get to Rome.  Is that enough to face the Praetorian Guard?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: The Felix Regiment will never be defeated.

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: I only have one question for you, General... Why?

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: You will lead an army of your brothers on Rome.  Many will die. Why?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I want Commodus dead.

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: That's not the reason.  Tell me the truth.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Because one night an old man whispered to me about a dream.  I will die for that dream.

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: I knew the old man well.  And I loved him very much.  In our youth we would spend hours building that dream together.  After he went to the wars and lost his way... I was very cruel.  I tormented him to remember that dream we spoke of.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: He did.

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: You can have no idea how much that means to me.

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: Any man who will die for a whispered dream deserves my respect.  I honor you, General.

Speaker: centurion
Dialogue: Madame, the Emperor would like to see you.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Caesar...

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: I am sorry to have kept you away... I needed this time to think...

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Of course...

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: I limited my world to these four walls so as to let my mind free... again and again my mind settles on but one question... What kind of world are we making when the people of Rome prefer a slave in the arena to their father?

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: It is my responsibility to make the world as it should be.  How is it I have made this world?

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Brother, do not be influenced by the mob.  They are a great, faceless beast --

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: They are not "the mob," Lucilla, they are the people.  They are my children and all I want to do is love them.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Our father loved Maximus... and I love him still... yet he defies me, he tasks me in front of my children. And they love him for it.  Just as Marcus loved him for it.  Tell me why, Lucilla.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: They see themselves in him.  They throw in their own sad dreams alongside his.  They think he fights for them.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: And what do I do but fight for them?!  I give them games to please them.  I strangle dissent to give them peace.  I empower the Praetorians to give them order. What more can I do?!

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Say I should fight him, in the arena.  Let my children see who the Gods truly favor.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: And what if he should win?

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: A God is more powerful than a man...

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Caesar, you let this unduly worry you.  At best he is a passing fancy -- he is a name, an image on a banner, ephemeral -- he will be forgotten as the next fancy appears --

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: But I need to know -- why do they love him?

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Mercy.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: He will not kill in the arena.  He is merciful.  As they all wish they were in their own hearts.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: And for that moment in the arena they are merciful too.  For a moment... they are Gods.  Offering life.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: But who can be more merciful than the Emperor of Rome?

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Brother... we've taken a sad path since we were children at Capri, have we not?

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: For my own part... I am sorry it came to this.  And to you alone of all men, I acknowledge my errors. And my regret.  I shall live with my sin for all my days.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: As will I, Commodus.  As will I.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: As the first act of my contrition I offer you the wooden sword of freedom.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Take it, brother.  Stand at my side as a free man worthy of your ancestors.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I only have ancestors because of you, brother.  You killed everything that ever lived alongside me.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Take it, Maximus.  Let us heal that fatal wound together.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: This is the new home you cursed me to.  And I am safer here from your treachery than I could ever be outside.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Will you always mistrust me?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Why don't you ask your father that?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I have more power as a slave in the arena than I could ever have as a free man.  As the Colosseum goes, the people go.  As the people go, the Empire goes.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: You think this is power?  I could show you power, slave --

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: No, Caesar... I will show you.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: The Felix Regiment will come from here.  We'll face the body of the Praetorians outside -- here.  Once inside, my archers will take up position to counter opposition inside the Colosseum.  I'll enter and join you -- we'll attack here --

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: -- a covert assault from within.

Speaker: vibius
Dialogue: We'll be killed.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Probably.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: But if we aren't... think of the glory.  Do you remember glory, Gladiator?

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: And if we die that day -- we die free men worthy of our ancestors.

Speaker: vibius
Dialogue: You didn't know my ancestors.  A rotten bunch.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Then be worthy of him.  The old Titan who would rather die bravely in a just battle than slink off to grow old and fat.

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: And impotent.

Speaker: vibius
Dialogue: If I die, I want a hundred whores at my funeral.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Where is my sister?

Speaker: handmaiden
Dialogue: She's out, sir...

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Where?

Speaker: handmaiden
Dialogue: I... don't know, Caesar.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Where is my sister?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Was it Centurion...?  General...?

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Captain.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: How did you know?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: A soldier knows a soldier.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: All that was a long time ago.  Too much wine and too many women.  And too much money.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: No --

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: This is who I am...  You see?  There was a time I would stand against ten men and never give an inch, spitting into the jaws of Hades all the while.  There was a time my heart swelled to strap on the armor of Rome.  But now...

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Now I am just an entertainer.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: You said something to me once.  You said in this life, we all die.  All we can choose is how we die.  And how we are remembered.  Do you recall those words?

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Then be remembered proudly.  This is your time, Proximo.  Stand at my side and be what you were.  What you truly are.  One last time.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: You might have spared yourself the speech, General.  The lady Lucilla bought all my gladiators two hours ago!

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: You pox-ridden bastard -- !

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: I am the richest trainer in the Empire!  And I will let my gladiators do anything you like! Conspire away, General!

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: But I tell you -- if you survive this madness I want you to go into business with me.  I'll give you a quarter of my holdings.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: A quarter?!

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: A third.  And not a hair more.  And you'll have to start in the provinces!  Cleaning up the lion shit!

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: You know, if you were half so awful as you pretend, you'd be a terrifying man.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Lucilla --

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Don't even say it.  I know it's dangerous -- but I had to see you. Captain Marcellus has gone to the army with your message as you instructed.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Good.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: He says the City Guard will be ready at the south road at noon.  They can only wait for an hour so --

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: You've told me this already.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Did I?  All right then.  So everything is prepared.  The Senate will be in attendance and you have your gladiators -- the usual cohort of Praetorians will be inside the arena --

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Lucilla... why are you here?

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Tell me honestly... please... do you think it will work?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Do you think we'll all die?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Will you swear something to me?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Will you swear it on the memory of your son?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: By all that you have ever loved... swear that if you survive you will take my son out of Rome.  Swear that you will go far away and never return.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I will.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: And if I should not survive... swear to me that you will honor my family in your prayers always.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: I will.

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Had I not been the daughter of Rome...

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Shhh... my heart breaks enough.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Sister... join us.  I've been reading to dear Lucius.

Speaker: lucius
Dialogue: I've been reading too.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Yes, he's a very smart little boy. He'll make a grand Emperor one day.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Join us, sister.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: We've been reading about the great Julius and his adventures in Egypt.

Speaker: lucius
Dialogue: She killed herself with a snake!

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: ... by his own blood... they whispered in dark corners and went out late at night and conspired and conspired...

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: But the Emperor Claudius knew that they were up to something dire.  He knew they were busy little bees. And one night he sat down with one of them and he looked at her and he said:  "Tell me what you have been doing, busy little bee, or I shall strike down those dearest to you. You shall watch as I bathe in their blood."  And the bee knew he spoke the truth, for the Emperor always speaks the truth.  And what do you think happened then, Lucius?

Speaker: lucius
Dialogue: I don't know, Uncle.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: The bee told him everything.

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Release them!  Release them all! ARM THEM!

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Come --

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: But --

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: If you want to live -- follow me --

Speaker: vibius
Dialogue: Go, Spaniard!  We'll show these Roman dogs how gladiators fight!

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: All the old gladiator schools have tunnels to the Colosseum -- most have long since collapsed --

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: How did they know?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: We were betrayed.

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: I'll stay here.  In case they follow.

Speaker: juba
Dialogue: Go!  Bring us the army!

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Quickly --

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Down that corridor is the butchery -- the blood sloughs lead to the Tiber.  Gods watch over you.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: You're not coming?

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: They are killing my men!

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: Gods... they're killing them all.

Speaker: lucius
Dialogue: What is that fire?

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Why that's a bonfire, Lucius.  I arranged it just for you.

Speaker: praetorian
Dialogue: Caesar...

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: Oh... that's for my sister.

Speaker: titus
Dialogue: By all the Gods...

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Old friend...

Speaker: titus
Dialogue: You're returned from Hades!  By all the Gods!

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Where is he?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I forgive you.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: With these hands I shall destroy your enemies so that you may sleep always and forever in peace.  From this day forth let it be known that I, Lucius Aelius Aurelius Commodus, have surmounted mortality.  That I, Lucius Aelius Aurelius Commodus, assume my destined place... at the side of the Gods.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: And as a righteous God, I shall ever protect you.  I shall cradle the world on my benevolent hands and clasp it to my heart.  So I have spoken!  And let the heavens tremble at my might!

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: This day I reclaim Rome for her people.  I shall give you the rebirth of your Empire!  Reborn and cleansed of her enemies!

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: I will make a new Rome!  Founded as it was at the beginning!  Archers -- GIVE US BLOOD!

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Throw down your weapons or we will kill you.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: FELIX REGIMENT!  DO HONOR TO YOUR ANCESTORS!  I SALUTE YOU!

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: As it was at the beginning so is it now.  The great She-Wolf of Rome will again suckle us, again ravage our enemies -- AND BRING US A WORLD REBORN!

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: So it was for Romulus and Remus, sons of Mars, so shall it be for us! The great She-Wolf will --

Speaker: lucilla
Dialogue: Remember your mother.

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: GET THE BOY!

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Captain?

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Where are they going?!

Speaker: proximo
Dialogue: This way!

Speaker: commodus
Dialogue: KILL THE BOY!

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: For my wife!

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: For my son!

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: For my father!

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: We who are about to die salute you.

Speaker: gracchus
Dialogue: General, the purple is yours if you so desire.  The Senate will support you.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: Rome... you are better than this. Look inside yourselves.  I challenge you to find your true voice.  Help the Senate speak for you.  Make them your champion... And dare to think what could be.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: I give you back the dream.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: When everything has calmed down, lead an orderly withdrawal.  Take them home.

Speaker: maximus
Dialogue: It doesn't look it now... but soon we'll have it growing again... Next year there will be vines, and then there will be grapes... It will be alive.
